justification: “Participants filled out the Behavior Identification Form (BIF; Vallacher, R. R. & Wegner, D. M., 1989). The BIF is a measure of level of construal and is sensitive to construal-level manipulations.”
“Participants next filled in the self-assessment manikins (SAM) used to assess the emotional dimensions of valence, arousal, and dominance along a nine-point scale (Bradley and Lang 1994).”

measured_by: Single-item Momentary Stress Scale (‘I feel stressed right now’)
justification: “Following the three SAM scales, participants were asked to rate how strongly they agreed with the following statement … ‘I feel stressed right now’ … (i.e. the Momentary Stress Scale).”
“In order to assess financial anxiety … participants then completed the Financial Anxiety Scale (FAS; Archuleta, Dale, & Spann, 2013).”
“Participants then completed the Financial Stress Scale (FSS) adapted from Hayhoe … the sum of the scores being indicator of financial stress.”
“After these, the participants completed the Financial Strain question (Feather, 1989).”
“The Financial Practices Index (FPI) … consists of 10 questions investigating various aspects of financial stability.”
“Participants then completed the Perceived Stress Scale (PSS; Cohen, Kamarck, & Mermelstein, 1983), with a higher PSS score … indicating higher general life stress.”
“They then completed the Financial Satisfaction scale (Robb and Woodyard 2011), with higher scores … indicating higher satisfaction with their financial situation.”
“First, they filled out the financial attitudes questionnaire, which consists of a series of 25 statements aimed at assessing attitudes towards finances and financial behaviors.”

“Participants then completed a budgeting task … They were asked to provide an estimate of how much of that total budget would be spent on … The percentage of total money spent on each category were used as dependent variables.”

“Next, participants completed a windfall spending task … where they were asked to imagine a scenario where they received an unexpected gift of $1000 USD … The amounts of money spent on each category were used as dependent variables.”

“Participants then completed a delay-discounting task aimed at investigating self-control, adapted from Fujita et al. (2006)… The difference between the immediate and delayed amounts … were used as the dependent variable to measure future discounting.”
“Participants answered six questions aimed at assessing (within-participant) framing bias, adapted from Mahoney … three gain-framed problems … and three equivalent loss-framed problems.”

measured_by: Three comparative likelihood questions adapted from Weinstein (1982)
justification: “Participants then completed a test assessing optimism bias related to financial outcomes, adapted from Weinstein (1982). They were asked … how likely is it that you will 1) Retire by age 65? …”

measured_by: Anchoring Bias Test using phone-number digits (Tversky & Kahneman, 1974)
justification: “Finally, participants completed an anchoring bias test, adapted from Tversky & Kahneman (1974) … The difference between the arbitrary anchor (the last two digits of the participant's phone number) and their own estimate … was used as a dependent variable.”
